awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II: Leveraging Z-axis Milled Fiber to Enhance the Performance, Economics and Sustainability of Carbon Fiber for High-Volume Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is the development of a high-performance, economic, and sustainable carbon fiber material and associated processing technology for consumer electronics, aircraft interiors, and mass market automobiles. In current processes, roughly 30% of carbon fiber is typically scrapped during manufacturing. By 2024, an estimated 50,000 metric tons of virgin carbon fiber will be scrapped and disposed in landfills. The proposed technology will extract value from scrapped fiber and prevent disposal, offering up to 25% cost reduction compared with carbon fiber products commercially available today. This technology creates higher usage and new opportunities for this advanced material.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will support the development of a high-performance composite that utilizes low-cost and sustainable milled carbon fiber.  An industrial roll-to-roll production process will be used to compound virgin carbon fiber with milled fiber.  These reclaimed fibers are oriented in the Z-axis using a proprietary technology adapted from an industrial process originally developed to make thermoset products.  The proposed project will develop a market-ready thermoplastic product with dense Z-axis reinforcement while retaining key in-plane properties. This new thermoplastic product will be targeted towards translation to high-volume consumer electronics, aircraft interiors, and automotive applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The NSF Phase II/IIB program funded the development of thermoplastic composite materials that feature Boston Materials’ proprietary Z-axis aligned carbon fiber (“Z-axis Fiber”) technology. The development has been focused on the infusion of thermoplastic polymers into the base “ZRT” film material. The process development of incorporating thermoplastic polymers was critical to unlock applications that require high-volume production and robust thermal and chemical stability. Prior to the Phase II/IIB program, Boston Materials had only the capabilities to produce thermoset (epoxy) composite materials, which greatly limited the markets and applications of the technology.

The program successfully lead to the development of new composite materials featuring Z-Axis Fiber for two key applications: heatsinks and fuel cell bipolar plates. 

Heatsinks

In applications that value low weight (mobile electronics, VR headsets, drones, aerospace, etc.), metal heatsinks can consume precious weight budgets. Certain applications also exist where the heatsinks are surface mounted to the heat-generating components with adhesives (pressure sensitive adhesives, thermal interface materials, thermal greases, etc.) and are vertically mounted, or subject to vibration/shock. In these applications, the high weight of metal heatsinks can lead to pre-mature debonding of the heatsink due to thermal creep in the adhesive. Applications that have high-power density and require robust reliability (such as servers, avionics, automotive sensors, medical equipment, etc.) have a demand for lighter weight heatsinks that reduce the thermal creep in adhesives that are used to surface mount the heatsinks. 

The NSF Phase II Program has lead to the development of specialized ZRT films that will enable the high-volume production of lightweight, polymer-based heatsinks that can match/exceed the cooling performance of metal, but at reduced weight.

Fuel Cell Bipolar Plates

The bipolar plate is a key component of a fuel cell stack – it passes the current generated within a fuel cell throughout the stack, ensures the proper flow of hydrogen and water, and maintains overall structure, all while withstanding the internal hot and corrosive conditions. Bipolar plates account for up to 80% of the overall stack weight. Accordingly, weight reduction in the bipolar plate has a significant impact on the energy and power densities on a gravimetric (weight) basis. Additionally, new manufacturing of bipolar plates can enable thinner plates, which increases energy and power density on a volumetric basis. 

The NSF Phase II Program has lead to the development of specialized ZRT materials that enable a 30% reduction in weight of thin bipolar plates for fuel cells.

 


Last Modified: 01/10/2023
Modified by: Anvesh Gurijala
